cyclone.name: IRMA
cyclone.current_location: about 65 mi E of Varadero, Cuba and 145 mi SE of Key West, Florida
cyclone.trajectory: Irma is expected to begin turning northwest later today, then move north-northwest Sunday, skirting the lower Florida Keys, riding up the southwest coast of Florida, and then moving inland across the Florida peninsula toward Georgia.
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: Florida Keys (near Key West) with a secondary coastal encounter near Naples–Marco Island, FL

weather_observation.watch_coast: North of Fernandina Beach to Edisto Beach, and west of the Aucilla River to Indian Pass (hurricane watch); storm-surge watch north of Volusia/Brevard County line to Isle of Palms, SC and north of Suwannee River to Ochlockonee River
weather_observation.warning_coast: Fernandina Beach southward around the entire Florida peninsula to the Aucilla River including Tampa Bay and the Florida Keys (hurricane warning); storm-surge warning Volusia/Brevard County line southward around the peninsula to Suwannee River including Tampa Bay
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Entire Florida peninsula and Keys, especially southwest and west-central coasts including Tampa Bay to Cedar Key
weather_observation.wind: Very strong winds are likely: tropical-storm force (gale) winds are almost certain (98% chance) and hurricane-force gusts are probable (64-kt probability 68% for nearby Tampa). Peak sustained winds at the port late Sunday night into Monday morning could reach 60–80 mph with higher gusts.
weather_observation.storm_surge: NHC surge forecast calls for 5–8 ft of inundation above ground from Ana Maria Island northward through Tampa Bay, which includes Port Manatee.
weather_observation.rainfall: 8–15 inches of rain with localized totals to 20 inches are possible over west-central Florida, bringing a significant flash-flood threat.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Isolated tornadoes in outer rain-bands, dangerous surf and rip currents in Tampa Bay and adjacent Gulf waters, plus prolonged port closure due to debris and high water.
